matched.actualTitle: Inadequate Input Validation - XSS Filter Bypass via Uppercase HTML Tags
matched.matchReason: Both findings identify the same XSS vulnerability in the /xss11 endpoint where input validation filters are inadequate and can be bypassed. The actual finding provides detailed analysis of how the regex filters `r"[\"']XSS[\"']"` and `r"<[a-z/]"` fail to prevent XSS attacks through quote breaking and event handler injection techniques. This directly corresponds to the expected finding about XSS filter bypasses in the name parameter filtering logic at lines 69-71.

extra.title: Missing Critical Security Headers (X-Frame-Options, X-Content-Type-Options, CSP, HSTS, X-XSS-Protection, Referrer-Policy)
extra.assessment: New discovery - legitimate security finding. The application lacks essential security headers that protect against clickjacking, MIME-sniffing, XSS, protocol downgrade attacks, and referrer information leakage. This is a valid and important vulnerability not included in the expected findings list.

extra.title: Server Version Disclosure - Werkzeug and Python Version Exposed
extra.assessment: New discovery - legitimate security finding. The application exposes Werkzeug 1.0.1 and Python 2.7.18 versions in HTTP response headers, enabling attackers to identify known vulnerabilities and target specific CVEs. Valid information disclosure vulnerability not in expected findings.

extra.title: Verbose Error Handling - Information Disclosure through Error Pages
extra.assessment: New discovery - legitimate security finding. The application uses default Werkzeug error pages that expose framework and version information, along with HTTP method enumeration through Allow header. Valid information disclosure vulnerability not in expected findings.

extra.title: HTTP Method Enumeration - Unnecessary HTTP Methods Exposed
extra.location: All endpoints (Allow header in OPTIONS and 405 responses)
extra.assessment: New discovery - legitimate security finding. The application exposes supported HTTP methods (HEAD, OPTIONS, GET) through the Allow header, enabling attackers to map application capabilities. Valid reconnaissance vulnerability not in expected findings.

extra.title: Use of Outdated and Vulnerable Python Version (2.7.18)
extra.assessment: New discovery - critical security finding. Python 2.7.18 is end-of-life (since January 1, 2020) with multiple unpatched CVEs including RCE, information disclosure, and SSL/TLS validation vulnerabilities. This is a critical infrastructure vulnerability affecting the entire application.

extra.title: Use of Outdated and Vulnerable Werkzeug Version (1.0.1)
extra.assessment: New discovery - legitimate security finding. Werkzeug 1.0.1 contains multiple CVEs (CVE-2023-25577 path traversal, CVE-2022-46489 XSS, CVE-2022-24765 DoS) and is severely outdated. Valid vulnerability not in expected findings.

extra.title: Missing HTML DOCTYPE Declaration
extra.assessment: New discovery - valid finding. Missing DOCTYPE declaration can cause browsers to enter quirks mode, potentially enabling certain XSS attacks and causing inconsistent rendering. Minor but valid security issue.

extra.title: Missing Cache-Control Headers - Improper Cache Configuration
extra.assessment: New discovery - legitimate security finding. Missing cache control headers allow unintended caching of sensitive pages, potentially exposing user data through proxy caches or shared browsers. Valid privacy and security vulnerability.

extra.title: Undefined Function causing Denial of Service in /xss11 Endpoint
extra.assessment: New discovery - legitimate security finding. The code calls undefined function `check_xss()` instead of `validate_user_content()`, causing NameError and HTTP 500 errors. This is a different issue from the XSS filter bypass - it's a code bug causing DoS.

extra.title: Potential Command Injection Through Unsafe Subprocess Usage - Improper Input Sanitization
extra.assessment: New discovery - critical security finding. While the current implementation uses list-based arguments (safer), the inadequate input validation combined with PhantomJS execution allows JavaScript/HTML injection in the file content. Risk escalation if subprocess is modified to use shell=True.

extra.title: SQL Injection Vulnerability - Inadequate Input Validation in Query Parameters
extra.assessment: New discovery - critical security finding. The regex filters allow all SQL injection payloads (7/7 tested payloads bypass filters) including authentication bypass, data extraction, and database destruction attacks. Valid vulnerability for future database integration.

extra.title: NoSQL Injection Vulnerability - MongoDB and CouchDB Injection Payloads Bypass Validation
extra.assessment: New discovery - critical security finding. All NoSQL injection payloads bypass the regex filters, allowing authentication bypass ($or operators), data extraction, and database manipulation. Valid vulnerability for future NoSQL integration.

extra.title: Server-Side Template Injection (SSTI) Vulnerability - Jinja2, EJS, and Pug Template Payloads Bypass Validation
extra.assessment: New discovery - critical security finding. All SSTI payloads (Jinja2 {{7*7}}, EJS ${7*7}, Pug #{7*7}) bypass the regex filters completely. Would lead to RCE if template engines are used for rendering user input.

extra.title: LDAP Injection Vulnerability - LDAP Query Metacharacters and Filter Injection Bypass Validation
extra.assessment: New discovery - critical security finding. All LDAP injection payloads (*))(&(uid=*), *)(|(uid=*, etc.) bypass filters completely. Would allow authentication bypass and directory enumeration if LDAP is used.

extra.title: XML External Entity (XXE) Injection Vulnerability - Filter Bypass via Inadequate Input Validation
extra.assessment: New discovery - legitimate security finding. All XXE payloads (8/8 tested) bypass the regex filters completely. Would allow local file disclosure, SSRF, and DoS if XML processing is integrated.

extra.title: Path Traversal and Local File Inclusion Risk - Directory Traversal Payloads Bypass Validation
extra.assessment: New discovery - legitimate security finding. All path traversal payloads (9/9 tested including ../../../etc/passwd, absolute paths, encoded variants) bypass the regex filters. Would allow unauthorized file access if application performs file operations.

extra.title: Sensitive Information Disclosure - Secret/Flag Stored in Plaintext File
extra.location: secret.txt file in application root directory
extra.assessment: New discovery - legitimate security finding. CTF flags are stored in world-readable plaintext file and loaded into global application memory. Valid information disclosure vulnerability undermining the security challenges.
